Thanks for the pointer - it sounds interesting.

My understanding of this i=
dea is that there are weird things along those lines that happen with indiv=
idual atoms and below that level.=C2=A0 But this does not apply (has never =
been observed) in normal life.=C2=A0 For instance, all the quantum theories=
 or disbelief in the world is not going to save us=C2=A0 if we lie down in =
traffic.=C2=A0 :)

      Frank did have a point there. There is some schools of th=
ought that suggest that nothuing existis outside of ourselves, that we perc=
eive and create our own realities. Things exist because we believe they do,=
 calling them into reality. If you have ever watched the movie/documentary =
'What the Bleep Do We Know?" it explains this in detail using scientific pr=
incipals.


I am not sure how much of it I agree with, but there is some tr=
uth to the thought that we create our own realities.

If you have not seen =
this movie, I can recommend it. Even of you don't agree with all of it, it =
does give you some interesting food for thought.

personally I don't think there is a fixed, fundamental reality. Just like t=
he wave/particle, it's whatever one thinks it is at that moment, for that p=
erson/test. 
=C2=A0When the they aim Hubble at a blank spot in space, and g=
ive it a long exposure, revealing billions of new galaxies--did those galax=
ies always exist, or did science wish them to exist-er theorize they exist?=
 and who can prove either way? Quantum "science" sugggests that everytime a=
nyone on the planet/universe has a discision to make an new universe is ins=
tantly created to accommodate both, kinda negates the speed of light speed =
limit wouldn't it, not to mention every other law of physics. 

=C2=A0
=C2=
=A0Yeah, I just don't see science being of much help with anything. 
=C2=A0=

Light is both a particle and a wave, dep=
ending on what you're looking for, or how you measure it.=C2=A0 That goes f=
or everything on the electro-magnetic (EM) spectrum, of which light is part=
, but gravity is not.


According to current science, there are 4 fundament=
al forces in the universe: EM is one, and gravity is another (and then the =
others I think are strong and weak forces at the atomic level).

=C2=A0 




Yes; if it happened now it would be visible 500 years from =
now. If it happened 500 years ago, it would be visible now.
=C2=A0
However,=
 there are people including Greg Hodowanec who have collected some evidence=
 that gravity waves are near instantaneous, and that if a supernova occurre=
d now, it could be detected now. Still, we wouldn't SEE it for 500 years. A=
nd=C2=A0the equipment=C2=A0described by Hodowanec (which I've built)=C2=A0c=
an't tell us WHERE the supernova occurred, just the fact it did.


Zack

Sorry to butt in, but I'm curious. If this is happeni=

n the delay before an individual hears it depending on how far they are fro=
m where the sound originated. Wouldn't it be the same with light?


~Draiga=
